column1: #Text=The  polycrystalline  compound  Ca2InOsO6  was  synthesized  by  means  of  a  solid-state  reaction.

#Text=Stoichiometric  amounts of CaO2 (Lab-made), Os (Heraeus, 100%), In (High Purity Chemicals, 99%), and KClO4 (Kishida Chemicals, 99.5+%)  powders  were  mixed  using  an  agate  mortar  in  an  Ar-filled  dry  box;  the  mixture  was  then  placed  into  a  Pt  capsule sealed on one side.
#Text=The Pt capsule was then sealed mechanically with a Pt cap by using a hand-powered press.
#Text=The fully sealed capsule was heated at 1400 °C for 1 h in a high-pressure apparatus capable of maintaining a pressure of  6  GPa  during  heating.
#Text=After  quenching  the  capsule  to  ambient  pressure  and  temperature,  the  compound  was  removed, ground, and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using Cu K radiation.

#Text=The structure refinement was done with the rietveld method using RIETAN_VENUS [17].The electrical resistivity () of Ca2InOsO6 was measured by the four-point method using a Physical Properties Measurement System (Quantum Design).
#Text=The electrical contacts on  the  four  points  were  prepared  from  Pt  wire  with  silver  paste.

#Text=The  magnetic  susceptibility  ()  of  Ca2InOsO6  was  measured for the polycrystalline compound with a SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design) in the temperature range 2  to  390  K,  under  both  field-cooled  (FC)  and  zero-field-cooled  (ZFC)  conditions.
#Text=The  magnetic-field  dependence  of  the magnetization of Ca2InOsO6 was recorded between +50 and 50 kOe at 5 K using the same apparatus.
